There was one minor upset in the Women's Knockout Team Championship. The 5th seeded team, led by Hjordis Eythorsdottir, from Huntsville, Ala., lost by 8 imps to the 12th seeded group, headed by Jan Martel of Davis, Calif. These are the pairings by captain in the quarterfinal stage today:
Martel vs. Joan Jackson of Dallas
Connie Goldberg of Merion Station, Pa., vs. Beverly Rosenberg of Sherman Oaks, Calif.
Kathie Wei-Sender of Nashville vs. Jean Hume of Livermore, Calif.
Cheri Bjerkan of Elmhurst, Ill., vs. Lynn Baker of Austin, Tex.

One of the contestants in the Spingold is the veteran star Sidney Lazard of New Orleans, who was inducted into the Bridge Hall of Fame here last Thursday. Almost half a century ago he was the hero of one the most remarkable deals in the history of the game, shown in the diagram.

In a rubber bridge game for high stakes, he held the South cards and heard his right-hand opponent bid one club. He passed quietly and was not surprised when the response of one spade was passed by East. That player had a reputation for making psychic opening bids when holding a long suit and a weak hand. The pass made it obvious to the other players that the opening was psychic.

In some difficulty, Lazard ventured two no-trump and heard three hearts on his left. It was now clear that West held a strong two-suiter, with at least 5-5 distribution. After considerable hesitation, East raised to four hearts.

Lazard judged correctly that East was wondering whether to give preference to spades, and his likely distribution was 3-4-1-5. North had to have considerable length in diamonds, so South made a dramatic leap to six diamonds, one of the most imaginative bids ever made.

Hearts were led, and South ruffed the second round with the ace. He cashed the king and led the nine to the jack, preserving a trump entry to the dummy. Ruffing dummy's remaining heart offered no hope of making 12 tricks, so Lazard led the club jack, forcing a cover with the queen.

After winning with the king, South cashed three of dummy's trumps, forcing East to come down to a singleton spade in order to preserve sufficient club protection. South finessed in clubs, cashed the club ace and reached this ending:

The club eight was led, and West reluctantly gave up a spade. Lazard ruffed and scored the last trick with the spade three, completing a virtuoso performance.
